This is not your average tough-guy anime. Not a typical comedy or coming of age. Kenichi uniquely blends together a variety of interesting aspects into a very enjoyable and well thought out series.
The story centers around Kenichi Shirahama, a mostly typical highschool boy who is unfortunately picked on and bullied for most of his life. But just as he's getting used to the idea, he meets a very unusual girl who changes his whole perspective. She does what he couldn't do: protect people. With that girl in focus, he determines he no longer wants to be pushed around and sets out to change himself throughmartial arts. But really, it seems that he bites more than he can chew, as he finds himself confronted with ever tougher opponents as things progress. But thanks to the girl, Miu Furinji, we find Kenichi training with five (sometimes six) of the best martial arts masters in the world.


The series does an excellent job building each character and makes everyone (besides random grunts) a joy to watch grow and open up as people. The masters are hilarious in how much they differ yet still come together to build something greater than the parts in Kenichi Shirahama. Even his former bully turned grudging friend, Haruo Niijima, is an interesting supporting character that provides exposition, builds situations, and offers comedic relief through a mischievous, methodical, ridiculous, self-centered, slimy persona that creates a real love/hate relationship for him.


Action scenes for this fighting-level anime are superb, not only giving intense matchups but describing a variety of moves and techniques that are pertinent to their respective styles. Seeing how things play out while learning some things along the way makes the fighting that much more interesting to watch, which reminds me of watching Initial D in that sense.


While being a comedy, with some romantic interest sprinkled in, Kenichi doesn't let that take him too far off track. Miu is really an amazing fighter, better than most of the enemies throughout the show, but is also a super nice, caring girl who becomes an excellent friend. This is a refreshing role to see a girl in, one that gets extended to other supporting rivals later in the series.


On top of all that, Funimation did an excellent job casting the characters and giving engaging dialogue that entertains all the way through. There are times when I do get tired of Funimation's recycling of their voice actors in all-but-typical roles which doesn't help with my suspension of disbelief. But I feel their choices here fit pretty well for the variety of characters they had to work with.


Overall, the show has great pacing, great comedy, great action and great characters. Although they do touch on some of the masters' backgrounds, I wish they had delved into some of the others some more. And I really wish weapons master Shigure was given more opportunity to show how she trains Kenichi. But the series otherwise pulls everything together thoroughly and keeps its focus on the battles to come.

This review only applies for the first 10 episodes of the series, it does not constitute for the overall experience of the anime itself and it will be comprised of what I liked/disliked about the anime and the reason I have had dropped it for. However, note that I've read about over 400 chapters of this manga at one point, so I am familiar with the events transpiring in the anime.
I never considered Kenichi to be a particularly good manga. I mean, it could be amusing at times despite the characters not being particularly filled with depth, but because they were simple, the author couldpull off a few gags that went on as comedic well enough, despite the humor being rather outdated with cliches and stereotypes. It could be interesting at times, by displaying certain principles of martial arts, despite continuously exaggerating the powers of its characters to a rather unnerving degree. The fact that there's a but to any praise I can give it, and a few other displeasing things with no buts, I'd call out Kenichi as a rather average comedic battle shounen. However, coupled with poor animation, which the anime does have, I'd recommend to steer clear of the anime.


The animation could be passable in standards of the late 90's perhaps, but even then I'd have fair examples from that time that do surpass it in animation, like Hajime no Ippo as one example, but Kenichi has aired in 2006, when things such as Death Note and Black Lagoon aired. Yes, these are some very different shows from Kenichi, but Kenichi has such poor animation, that in comparison to those shows, it feels like it should've been released 10 years prior. I mean, excluding the aspect ratio being 4:3, which can be considered passable at the time, Kenichi relies too heavily on speed lines to show off fast movement, has pisspoor shading, like you can perhaps see in the picture MAL uses for the show, but not as bad. It also uses motion pictures to display hits that are impactful, blue backgrounds with shifting levels of blurred out white to simulate motion that could be acceptable when you run out of budget for maybe one or two fight scenes, but not all of them. All in all, the animation for any fight scene is simply hogwash because it all looks dull and poorly made. The fact that the character designs in the show and the manga look like bodybuilder rejects that got sentenced to go live in a japanese highschool for abusing steroids, does not help with any early hooks, and any other designs look pretty blandly shounenistic.


What you'd be missing out by skipping this anime is a few poorly animated sequences about some loser that decided to take action against the people that were making fun of him, alongside his crush, some big blonde klutzy tits, as well as some gags about his masters, that have some tropes attached to them as well. Personally I find it pointless watching an action series that is simply poorly animated, but if you're that curious, know that it is pretty much like most other shounens. It starts with a loser incapable of fighting that will develop himself in order to be able to protect the weak/his friends/the weak & his friends. Evil is wrong because being evil is wrong and all that morallistic bullshit, to the point where they reach two paths in martial arts between people that use martial arts to kill and people that fight with martial arts that don't kill. The characters are gonna undergo some love chain where x has a crush on y for the most part and villains are eventually gonna become friends of the protagonists in a cartoonish manner, where they change sides because they lost and any villanous traits are forgiven. Eventually the show after abandoning deliquent fights, it becomes about the confrontation of people that use their fists to kill and the people that don't, and it constantly undergoes a moral enbargo. It also starts relying more on ecchi and showing as many nipple shots as it can as the story goes on. Gotta make those sales somehow. The driving hook for the fights will be how over the top the powers they display are and how the characters progress in their training, but that all becomes dull, because the show has a reliance on buffing up characters every time to make a higher threat than the former. Upping up the ante how many times will impress the viewer? There is a limit, and Kenichi has no idea where that threshold should stop.


To conclude, History's Strongest Disciple Kenichi is a poorly animated battle shounen that relies on tropes and exaggerated powers to hook its viewers. It  gets rather repetitive as it progresses and the only enjoyment that I'd say you can get out of it, is if you're in the same line of humor as the show is, and that often revolves about exaggerated sequences of traiting and the characters oogling on women. There are a few punch lines that can work from the training, due to the sheer ridiculousness of it, but ultimately, I think there are far better alternatives to Kenichi, which I can say that it doesn't really have anything unique in its execution, and in both animation and mentality of the characters, feels quite dated. It can be watchable, if you're a fan of shounens and are merely looking for something to watch casually as a shounen, as it will proceed being comedic and upping up the ante. But that's the basic formula used to sell this type of stuff. And if you're one person that buys into it, Kenichi should work well on you, despite its shortcomings.

At first I was sceptical, because after all most martial arts anime are not that well done, mainly due to the difficulty trying to try complex styles, moves, and attacks. the art isn't the best, I didn't exactly like the style that was used in this series, but as I watched more and more I found that it wasn't to bad, and was bearable. and that the style began to fit with the pace the anime was flowing and the moves that were being shown.
The characters are well diverse, especially Kenichis 5 masters, ranging from Karate, Weapons, Chinese Martial arts, Jiu Jitsu, Muay Thai. eachof them having their own unique personality and been very strong and fast.


The story is upon Kenichi a weak and cowardly boy, who wants to learn karate to become stronger. due to his shortness and weak build, he is bullied in the school dojo and challenged to a duel that who ever loses will have to quit karate. Kenichi accepts, and is troubled, and stumbles upon a blonde girl interfering in local yakuza bullying an old man, Kenichi fearing the girl will lose her life rushes to her aid with not even a thought, only to realise he was going to die. It was during this time the girl saves him with her amazing skills. and introduces him to her dojo.


The anime series, flows well, and makes alot of sense in some way. because as kenichi becomes stronger and defeats a strong opponent he attracts more stronger opponents who want to defeat him.


This series is full of action and comedy and ecchi scenes. and also its just fun to watch someone become stronger and making alot of allies.

This anime is a great way to start this story. This is the first story arc from the manga series, and it's adapted fairly well. The manga has a bit more ecchi and better artwork, but the anime stays in tune with it's comedy. Beware of the synopsis for this, it's a little off, but it does cover a couple of the basics.
Kenichi is picked on by literally everyone at school. The story starts with this weakling attempting to protect a girl (that really doesn't need his protection at all) from a few thugs. In his attempt to "save" her, she sees something in himand they become friends. The synopsis is right on about the karate club, and Furinji Miu (the girl he befriends) teaches him his first basic moves so he doesn't get destroyed. He has no talent whatsoever (this is key) but his hard work and practice pays off. Now he's in over his head and Furinji Miu takes him to her father's dojo where the strongest fighters in the world have gathered. He begins his intense training one style on top of another, but he doesn't realize the world he's just fallen into. His driving motivation is to surpass Miu so that he can be strong enough to protect her.


This story is filled with so much comedy, and the fighting scenes are great. The manga is a must read, and this is a great introduction to the manga. It's hard not to respect Kenichi, he has an incredibly strong character when the chips are down, but in daily life he still cowers from delinquents (though he could easily mop the floor with them thanks to his training). There are a lot of valuable lessons of friendship, doing the right thing, standing up for what you believe in, and more.

Being the type of person that quickly finishes one series to move onto the next there are very few that stand out that I know I have to re-watch.
History's Strongest Disciple Kenichi is one of those few animes that I've found to really grab me with the character development that I found to be the major point of me watching it. From episode 1 to 50 you see a wide variety of growth that you'd expect and almost want to see from the various characters in the show. From the awkward relationship between Kenichi and Mui to various others you meet throughout the show.
I foundpersonally, with how Kenichi acts he is able to draw people around him much to the likes of Luffy or Naruto are able to in their own series.


Story : It gets going quickly off the start with some filler here and there but is quite often VERY entertaining and showing a lot of growth in characters. I never found during the storyline of the anime to come to a stop, it was always progressing forward.


Art : What to say, it was like Dragon Ball Z meets Street Fighter (you'll see what is meant by this if you make it through the series). I really enjoyed the look and feel, even with the very childish parts.


Sound : A great soundtrack can make or break a series, this one helped to move the series along and really draws you in. The characters are done amazingly and all the sounds sound very natural as to what you would think.


Character : Without spoiling anything, if you love character development and growth. Humor and seriousness than there's no much more to say.


Enjoyment : 10/10, why? I could not go without watching 6+ episodes at a time. Moving from one fight to the next you would always want to see where the story was going to take you and make you laugh all along the way.


Overall : MUST WATCH! Even if you're not a "sports anime fan" this is in a whole different category that the Naruto/Bleach fans and the Prince of Tennis fans can both call a middle ground. If you haven't had the chance to see it, give it a try I can say that it only gets better as the show goes on.

Story 6/10

Well where should I start...
Kenichi is simply a masterpiece.. No matter what type of Anime you are generally Into, you'll like Kenichi.. No infact you'll love it.
It has a great story, tons upon tons of humor and the best part is that it doesn't get dumb or idiotic... Everything fits right where you feel it should.
Very often its even unpredictable, wich is very unusual for Anime (tbh, 95% of all Anime you can TELL whats gonna happen next during crucial scenes)
This Anime has it all... What stops me from giving it max art and sound score,  is because theres a certain character that obviouslyis there for the comedy side, but doesn't really do so well in my honest opinion... sometimes, but often ends up failing at it, leaving you wanting more of the amazing story instead of watching that.


This character you'll likely end up ignoring most of the time, but that is FAR from spoiling the Anime, luckily the time this person pops up isn't that frequent :D


After watching this Anime, you'll end up wanting more.. Hence why i've watched Kenichi probably 7-8 times over and over again... Many series I rewatch I end up fast forwarding to the funny/crucial/best parts, but not Kenichi... Kenichi I watch every episode, even the intros... Because it is a masterpiece.


PS, one of the main chars have huge boobies, another reason to run off and watch it asap.

A light-hearted action comedy that starts out relatively grounded and then dives into the impossible. The artwork overall is fair, some episodes are better than other, and occasionally you can tell the studio went in for the cheap so they could save up for more cinematic fights later on. The storyline is interesting, but gets ridiculous by the end. Still, I found myself watching just to see what kind of shenanigans would happen next. 
This is definitely geared towards a younger male viewing demographic. Some of the fan-service is ridiculous and bordering on uncomfortable, but I suppose it draws attention. 
Overalll, an enjoyable tale aboutself-respect, courage, friendship, and learning to stand on your own two feet.

Well this is the first anime in a while that’s driven me to watch it one episode after another until I eventually collapse into bed from exhaustion only to awake to do the same again.
While it does make for wonderful viewing it can sometimes make a series hard to digest as your consuming the entire stream of the story rather than the "bite-size" pieces it’s usually served up in. It also works best with shows that have a continuous narrative as opposed to an episodic approach.
Needless to say Kenichi has such a format and as such made for extremely enjoyable viewing. Story wise it’s afairly basic spin on the classic shonen martial arts series. What really makes it appeal though is the interesting and appealing characterisation of the protagonists (and antagonists).


Another huge appeal for me was the fact that in many ways the entire show could be seen as one long training session interspersed with bouts of action and character development side pieces. While this may not appeal to everyone (because some people are clearly deviant bastards) it really appeals to me. I really love those bits in martial art films, books, anime, etc. where after been beaten the hero goes of into the mountains or seeks out a reclusive master to learn new techniques and increase his power. In many ways such training scenes are as enjoyable for me as the fight scenes. And the more mental the training the better it is (e.g. Drunken Master).


As Kenichi contains training nearly every other episode I really liked that facet of it as it mixed all my favourite martial art genre tropes into a nice cohesive whole.


It's also quite an amusing show, though sometimes the jokes do require (fairly basic) knowledge of other fighting anime/manga series.


I suppose the main downside to Kenichi is the fact that there are only fifty episodes in the first season and as the manga is still ongoing it’s clear that the story isn’t finished in these fifty episodes. Though it is a fully contained story arc and only one main plot thread is left open so while it leaves the viewer wanting more it certainly doesn’t leave them feeling cheated.

This was such a refreshing series! It's incredibly entertaining, with great fight scenes, and a lot of humor. Some decent fanservice as well. The story itself isn't very creative, but it's the characters that make this show. The MC starts out a weakling, but through rigorous hard work and training (with 5 masters in different martial arts teaching him) he is able to become very strong by the end of the series.  Also the MC is kind of like Naruto, in the way that he naturally turns enemies into friends by just being himself and doing what he feels is right.

History’s Strongest Disciple Kenichi is a Shounen, Action, Comedy about a typical high school boy (Kenichi) who’s always being bullied, until one day, he learns of a special dojo that teaches many forms of martial arts.
Its a nice anime , and realistic too its not like bleach or naruto with beams or something its just good martial arts and a lot of fights i liked this anime , if u are wanting to watch a realistic epic fight anime than go watch kenichi.

Great characterization, great humor and great study into all kinds of martial arts, for those who love fighting based Anime, History's Strongest Disciple Kenichi is for you.
Kenichi Shirahama, a young man who has always had a fascination with the martial arts one day has a fateful encounter with a certain someone that would change his life forevermore...that someone was Miu Furinji, a beautiful and talented martial artist who would introduce Kenichi into the world of true martial arts...
Upon discovering Kenichi's interest into practicing martial arts and because of his strong moral desires to protect those that he cares about, Miu introduces Kenichi to her familydojo of Ryozanpaku, where 6 of the greatest martial arts masters of all time gather together and live with one another, Kenichi wonders to himself, upon meeting with these 6 masters trained in a different area of the martial arts each respectively...how is it that they haven't killed each other already!? a puzzle that continues to circle around in Kenichi's mind even after joining Ryozanpaku and becoming the dojo's very first disciple.


As for the masters themselves:


Shio Sakaki-A master of Karate who loves to drink and ride bikes, although he has a gruff demeanor, big down he's just a big softie although he would most probably "kill" anyone who would ever mention that.


Akisame Koetsuji-A master of Jujitsu and may very well be the incarnation of Buddha himself, he has trained his body to near superhuman peak conditions and likes to spend his time talking about philosophy, he has a clinic next to the dojo.


Kensei Ma-A master of Chinese Kenpo who is a comedic lech and tries to both bribe and tempt Kenichi into buying one of his dirty magazines, despite his eccentric personality however, he is a true practitioner of martial arts, he is also skilled in using therapeutic needles.


Apachai Hopachai-A master of Muay Thai, he is the most gentle and fun loving of all the masters, he gets along well with everyone although some people find him to be scary due to his humongous size, Apachai has trouble in holding back his sheer strength during training.


Shigure Kosaka-A master of all kinds of weaponry and the most reserved of the 6 masters, however, she tends to open up from time to time, showing an almost humorous side to herself, she keeps a pet mouse by her side at almost all times named Tochumaru.


Finally last but especially not least


Hayato Furinji-Miu's grandfather, the owner of Ryozanpaku and of whom is considered to be the Japanese Superman, to this day, no other master of the martial arts in history has surpassed him in both strength and wisdom alike, he hides his motives very well...


With these 6 masters, Kenichi definitely wonders...will he be able to survive all of the training they are about to put him through!? however, should he master the training, he may very well just become not just Ryozanpaku's greatest disciple but also history's greatest disciple...history's strongest disciple Kenichi Shirahama.


The series of History's Strongest Disciple Kenichi is definitely both a good read and watch, it has an in depth analysis of almost every real life martial arts known to the world and whilst that is indeed one of its strengthening points, it may also complicate viewers.


The major praise of the series in this Review however goes towards the strongly developed individual characters and the story that allows them to be who they naturally are, full of comedic insanity and pure gentle kindness.


The masters of Kenichi in particular show very strong character developments, as his mentors, they know when to be strict and teach him about how life is an ever winding circle full of battle, thus preparing him for all kinds of fights that he may very well get involved in whether of his choosing or not.


For Kenichi Shirahama himself, he is a very strong protagonist full of determination and idealism, unlike most Shonen genre based series main protagonists, Kenichi is a unique individual in the sense that once he declares something and he intends to do it, he will not change his mind in the slightest, no matter who stands in his way, what makes this unique about him is that unlike other primary protagonists who tend to throw away their morals during fights, Kenichi refuses to do that whatsoever at all, he is strong willed and refuses to change his mindset especially even during fights, for example, whenever Kenichi finds himself in a battle against a woman, he will not raise even a pinky finger against them, he wishes to stay true to what are his principles, even if it means certain death...Kenichi is inspiring in this regard because his stubborn will to remain gentlemanly, as it were and not obey the laws of survival of the fittest can maybe, not 100% certainly but just maybe help those who are pessimistic in real life about the concept of survival of the fittest stay true to the morals and principles they have placed for themselves, becoming a little if not slightly more optimistic about the future ahead of them...


However, there is one fatal flaw in Kenichi's character that i wish to point out to viewers, because he falls in love with Miu, sometimes because of a vow he makes to himself to protect Miu no matter what does it appear that he is borderline obsessed with her if not more so, sometimes it might put viewers off the potential budding romance between the two.


As for Miu herself, she is a strong and independent heroine of the series, she fights in the places that Kenichi refuses to, picking up the slack, if that is the correct term of expression to use for those moments, although a fierce warrior at heart, she does not hide a more sociable and attractive side to herself, the latter playing into her character overall.


Fair warning about the series, it is heavily Ecchi based, although a true fighting based series to be sure, Ecchi is used a lot of the time in the action scenes and could be considered, as a weak point to the tone and structure of how the story is played out.


What History's Strongest Disciple Kenichi fails in some areas, it makes up for in  others, the series itself could be considered a hidden jewel among Shonen genre based Manga/Anime, it is popular but funnily enough not so much considered popular in the same regards that Fairy Tail, Fullmetal Alchemist and Soul Eater are to more Western based audiences.


But perhaps that is for the best, the adventure of finding something new fulfills a person in a way, don't you agree?


Story, Art, Sound, Character, Enjoyment and Overall, especially Story and Character are all worthy of praise, i strongly recommend giving the series a try and see what you think of it, it may or may not start an interest into pursuing an area of martial arts that you like.


Martial arts is not the study of fighting but the study of training one's inner self both physically and mentally, to learn the martial arts is to learn more about one's spirit and how it is currently balanced and what can be done to properly balance it, the essence of martial arts is to find inner peace within one's self through the channeling and the movement of the body, to access a person's Chi is a result of the ever ongoing training of martial arts, it begins but never ends, a reflection of the circle of life we all live in, it may not benefit any noteworthy results but there is one result that is most certainly noteworthy: the mastery of peace and balance within one's heart, body and spirit.


You could say that is the whole lesson that all martial arts practitioners learn upon completing its forms of art, i honestly would not really know, as i don't study martial arts but i'm guessing that's what the final result could possibly turn out to be.


Anyways, here's hoping this Review was helpful in any way.

This is anime is adapted from one of my favorite mangas. I completed the manga that this anime was adapted from and it is amazing! The anime only covers over about 1/4 of the whole manga, which is a shame because the best part picks up after the ending of this anime. The OVA that follows gives you a close glimpse, but it still doesn't do justice to the manga so I can understand some peoples frustration with the anime. If I had not read the manga I would have probably ranked it an 7 or 6. I really hope the remaining story line gets animated in the near future, I am sure many MAL users agree with me.

BEWARE! THE AWESOMENESS OF THIS ANIME IS TOO ADDICTING!  YOU WERE WARNED!!!  
The anime follows the exploits of Shirahama Kenichi; your average student who's always bullied (thus earning him the nickname "Weak legs"). One fateful day, he meets Furinji Miu (a fellow student) who helps him overcome his fears and he begins training at the Ryouzanpaku Dojo under six exceptional martial artists.....
Every episode will have you dying from fits of laughter; the gags aren't overused hence they never get old. The action and fight scenes aren't over-the-top (just the right amount of reality + unbelievable). Art style is pretty good, sounds used suitthe situations and convey the feelings the animation's staff want to portray and a great storyline that won't leave you confused.\n
In my view, the anime's strength lies in its characters and their development: varied, easy to relate to, humorous, interesting past etc. The makers paid close attention to these aspects (especially Niijima........I loved how they introduced him as an annoying pest and somehow managed to transform him into one of the funniest, likeable characters in the show).\n\n
Downsides? Only a few: Odin's reason for fighting was absolute trash in my opinion. Sadly Kenichi and Miu's relationship never progresses past friends. Why did this anime have to end at episode 50? This aired in 06-07 and it definitely deserves A LOT more seasons. For those who cannot get enough of it, it continues at chapter 144 in the magna. I definitely recommend picking it up. \n\n
All in all, it is shounen, martial arts masterpiece. \n
It will grab you from the first episode and not let go; quickly getting you hooked........when it is over, you will definitely be craving for more...

The story is about a boy named Kenichi who's nicknamed "weak legs". Kenichi is often picked on due to his soft nature. The story doesn't seem like anything special at the beginning, however the story quickly starts to pick up and become exciting once Kenichi joins Ryozanpaku. After that we get introduced to a world filled with strong and interesting characters and obstacles Kenichi has to overcome. Through these tough experiences Kenichi makes friends, grows as a character and earns a reputation for himself. The way this series executes Kenichi's growth is exciting and well done. Despite the fact that Kenichi learns to fight forthe purpose of getting these bully's off his back he manages to become infamous and gain the attention of even stronger enemies. I found it hilarious as Kenichi became more infamous the more enemies he defeated. 


The characters are one of the best aspect in this series. Ryouzanpaku's masters each have distinct and likeable personalities. It's heart warming to watch Kenichi bond with his masters on a personal level and watch characters friendships form and strengthen with one another as they each go through hardships together. Once enemies but now friends. This is one of the reasons I love this series so much. Each of the voices for the characters suit them perfectly and do a good job at complementing their personalities.


The art is very colourful in this anime and the animation for the movements are well done. I personally love the opening and ending songs. They suit the series perfectly. I love feel good anime/manga which is why I like this series so much and the opening and credit songs do a good job capturing the feel of the series.


This series is really enjoyable if you like martial arts, comedy, great fights and friendship. I definitely recommend this if you're looking for a fun series with great characters and a good story.

It combines funny characters with matial arts gang warring and a main character who starts out as naive and weak, but becomes naive and stong! The fighting goes from pedestrian to over-the-top, especially with Kenichi's 5 Martial arts masters. I fell in love with this show because the characters are so entertaining and and the story is very engrossing in a laid-back sort of way.
Kenichi is a pathetic wimp who gets bullied in school. He meets a girl who lives at a dojo and she invites him to come to the dojo to train in martial arts. Little does he know, there are 5 mastersat this dojo who all have inhuman skills in various martial arts. They train him until he is on the verge of death so he can become a strong martial artist as fast as possible. He attracts the attention of the local martial arts gang and has to take on their members throughout the show. If you like funny, happy, action-packed shows, then at least give this a try.

This show was surprisingly enjoyable. I'm no fan of shounen, and it is not a supreme masterpiece, but this anime manages to provide good comedy mixed with fighitng, and maintains good pacing throughout most of its episodes. Definitely recommended.
Story:
Good and fairly simple. Final conflict was a bit underwhelming, but the story mostly worked as a background for comedic plots and it worked for those purposes well. There's wide array of gags, running gags, etc.
Art:
Above average. Characters are a bit more detailed than what you'd usually see in anime with lower budget. There's barely any reused scene (i've spotted about two), characters are not cookie-cutter (visually).
Sound:
Decentmusic, solid voice work. I've recognized voices of Motoko Kusanagi (from GiS) and Yakumo Tsukamoto (School rumble). \n\n
Characters:\n
Characters are fairly stereotypical, but there's great deal of character development going on. Characters change over time, cheir personalities change as well, they grow stronger, etc. The interactions are mostly slapstic comedy (although it isn't very cliched on its own), but those interactions are amusing. Characters are memorable, for example, protagonists's sister was one of the most amusing "little sister" characters I saw. Protagonist steadily grows in strength and his character transforms along the way.\n\n
Enjoyement:\n
Near the end of the series where the series lost their momentumn and started stretching fights for too long. There weren't a lot of those, though. Overall I found it interesting to watch due to comedy element.\n\n
Overall:\n
It is 50 episodes, but the quality of series is surprisingly good. It does occasionally have darker sadder moment, but it does not obsess over them, and is mostly on lighthearted side. There are better animes, of course, but there's not THAT many of them, and this anime works great when you need to relax/unwind. \n\n
So, recommended.

Before I start this review I'd like to say that I have not seen the whole series, but I have seen half of it and I believe it's enough to give the gist of what this series is about. So anyways, on to the review. The story is basically about your average cowardly kid named Kenichi Shirahama who isn't very strong and is always being picked on constantly, because of this he attempts to learn Martial Arts through books which didn't work very well obviously. Kenichi then meets this girl Miu who after beating up and saving Kenichi from a gang of thugs offers himto train at her dojo. Unfortunately Kenichi did not know what kind of dojo this was and agreed. This is where he meets the masters which he will be trained by. There are 5 masters and  each are masters of their art, these arts are Muay Thai, Karate, Weapons, Jiu Jitsu and Kung Fu. Overall the story is enjoyable and even good for the most casual anime fans. The characters are fun  and the way the characters interact  can give quite the good laugh. It teaches you that you must work very hard towards a goal and it does not come easy, which is shown through Kenichi's training.  The fights scenes are great to watch and aren't over very over the top, the fights can actually become quite technical and every movement and attack has an explanation behind it. Another great thing about this anime is that everything Kenichi learns is applied time after time in each fight. Overall if you if are interested in Martial or train in the Martial Arts like myself you will probably enjoy this anime and will get excited to see many of the techniques you've seen or have even done yourself, in the anime being used. If anything at least give this anime a try, it's not the best anime ever made but it is a very fun watch.

It kept me entertained/happy/laughing and generally wanting more i just loved every part of it and i hope anyone who listened to this review will enjoy it as much as i did unfortunately they ended it off and just left it to the manga which made me a sad panda but i guess ill have to start reading manga from here on.


8 for art

Ive never usually cared for visuals but the art in this anime contributed to what made it so enjoyable and watchable.


7 for sound

The same thing as art apply's to sound but i rather enjoyed the soundtrack and the various sounds throughout the series.


10 for character

Kenichi his masters and his friends all have something interesting and a good quality to them its nice to see how they start to show their true nature.


10 for enjoyment

I cant help but stay i loved this series it is close to my heart as one of my favourites and will remain that way for as long as i live (throws out hand yelling "SHINPAKU").


9 overall

i would have gave it a 10/10 if they kept the series going all the way to the end of the manga but beggars cant be choosers i guess oh well i hope you enjoyed my review bye everybody

As a fan of martial arts anime, this is one enjoyable and funny story. A typical wimp trying to get stronger because he wants to protect something.
the most enjoyable is how kenichi  develops new and powerful movement's mixing various styles and trying to catch- up with the girl he loves.
music and background are not a masterpiece but they are good to be honest the characters make-up for everything.Thanks for reading my review

this anime proves that good characters is the start of a good story. the plot it self is very simple martial arts. The main character gets stronger and stronger and stronger as his enemies get stronger and stronger and stronger. its the basic shonen plot. the art is nothing special bright solid colors nothing really eye catchy (but it does not really bother me) the sound is decent. the strength in this anime is the characters. all of them are really fun both the good and bad ones. putting these characters in a simple plot and play with them is wat gives birth to thishighly enjoyable serice

Story: Very straightforward plot line. There is very weak foreshadowing and is, at most times, quite predictable. In other words, it's a simple story that's uniformly recognizable.
Art: I, personally, found the animation to be slippery. "Slippery" meaning that there were a lot of coloring and  errors within the simple movements of the characters. Though the "slippery" quality tended  to get in the way of me watching the show, the gems within the show had to be the sequences with the  fights and most of the training with Kenichi freaking out the entire time. However, it seems that the animation gets better everycouple episodes. There is hope.


Sound: FUNimation products never cease to amaze me and Kenichi is no exception. However, I believe that, the sound quality is too good for the animation that is provided in the show thus far. The casting and line producing  were wonderfully orchestrated in all aspects. The voices match the character and vice versa. 


Character: The main characters all seem to have a distinct personality but not to the point of complete predictability. The "bad guys" seem some what generic as well as some of Kenichi's own traits. These characters defiantly drive much of the story line.


Enjoyment: Over-all, this anime was/is fun to watch. The dub was what, honestly, got me through some of the poorly done animation sequences. The fighting sequences were wonderful to watch and you feel like you're learning along with Kenichi once you get into it. 


Overall: Wonderful show to watch and to be introduced into the heavy shonen/fighting anime genre. The animation isn't up to par with the way it sounds and I hope that the story becomes more complicated soon.

Well if your looking for good action which keeps you at the edge of your seat with the occasional light hearted humor to it then this is an ideal anime. Its high on entertainment and fast moving, although some people do suggest that the plot can get kinda repetitive but i dont mind that one bit and wouldnt have it any other way. Well kenichi as an anime has great animation and flawless action, although the sound track is average. In my opinion the only down side to it is that the plot can tend to get a bit week at a few points, buti highly recommend it as a must see anime, even if your not a fan of martial arts. \n
P.S: The girls in Kenichi are amazing =3
